Author: nostrademons
Title: What's The Optimal Number Of Co-Founders For A Startup? 2.09!

Author: danielha
Content: It being March, many of these events have since passed. There are still a number to look forward to, including the Web2.0 Expo in April and Summit in October.

Author: e1ven
Content: I would suspect that here, they pull you directly away from your current projects, to work on the new Startup- This isn't 20% time, it's "Work on your own time until you have a good prototype.. Then, 100% time"

Author: e1ven
Content:
This reminds me a bit of the Bell Labs west-coast startup program. Back in the 1990s, they created their internal startup area.

While it did do was create a lot of hostility, and keeping of secrets from other divisions. It divided the company up, and most of the internal groups didn't end up doing well..

Check out "Bell Labs: Life in the Crown Jewel", it's an interesting read on the history of the labs.

It seems that independent (external) funding sources can do much better- They can fund any group that shows promise, no matter where it originated.. They put the risk into the hands of the founders, and they have a wider market to choose from.

-C

Author: abstractbill
Title: Marc Andreessen's latest startup - allows users to create social networks

Author: chendy
Content:
Spotplex seems to be down currently, so I haven't been able to fully explore the site. However, based on the Techcrunch coverage, it seems like this will ultimately be just another content suggestion site. I like the innovative way of sourcing stories, but at the end of the day, it will just be another wall for news to echo off of. If a story makes it to the front page of Spotplex, there's a good chance we'll see it on Digg. And then Reddit. And so on.

However, Spotplex will ultimately garner a different type of reader base, so it should provide some variety from that standpoint. Not to mention, now we're getting one step closer to our news feeders becoming "self aware."

Author: Elfan
Content: What's interesting is that FF3 may allow you to use webapps offline.

Author: amichail
Content: I like it, and yes, I'm sure you can combine it with social networks to get something compelling (e.g., you can make it cheaper to send email to people who have designated you as a friend, etc.).  It's strange to see the overwhelmingly negative reaction on TechCrunch though.
